title: What happens to velocity, when mass is increased and kinetic energy is the same? - Quora

response.answer_text: If mass is increased with the same kinetic energy, then velocity decreases as long as we are talking about speeds that are substantially less than the speed of light. Kinetic energy KE=1/2mv^2, so v=(2KE/m)^-1/2, but once you get to relativistic speed with speeds close to the speed of light, then both mass and KE increase fast as we get closer and closer to light speed, and the energy may increase exponentially even further with rapid msss increase. We are referring to like at 99.99999% of the speed of light… Kaiser T, MD.

Velocity will fall rapidly as mass increases, provided the K.E remains constant. (Specifically if you double the mass, the velocity will fall by a factor of 4, if you triple the mass, by a factor of 9 etc.etc.)
